content: rustic roads by christine welsh - windy hill knitworks this scarf is simple enough for a beginner yet has plenty of texture and details crocheted longwise using half-double_crochet stitches with double crochet trim on the ends ending in a fun twisted fringe stitching in the back loops in half-double crochet creates an interesting braid-like effect well suited for bulky yarns with long color striping sequences this example uses bernat symphony yarn approx 300 yards bulky hook size j gauge not critical size approx 78 long 6 wide stitches used foundation half-double_crochet fhdc * single_crochet single_crochet half-double_crochet half_double_crochet back loop only blo double_crochet double_crochet slip_stitch slip_stitch body row 1 fhdc 200 stitches place stitch marker on first and last stitches row 2-12 chain 2 and turn half_double_crochet in blo across move stitch markers up to first and last stitches each row to help keep edges neat and even edge row 1 turn scarf and working into the edge single_crochet 17 stitches evenly across row 2-4 turn chain 3 counts as 1 double_crochet double_crochet in 2nd st and each st across 17 stitches page 1 of 2 fringe turn chain 1 *draw up an 8 inch loop of yarn place finger into the loop and twist the yarn 20 times reinsert hook into the loop and slip_stitch into the blo of the same stitch the loop will twist down on itself you may need to gently pull on the loop to straighten it out slip_stitch into the next 2 stitches and repeat from * across 9 fringes fasten_off attach yarn on second edge and repeat twisted fringe will be about 1/2 the length of the loop before twisting if you want longer or shorter fringe adjust the size or the loop using a ruler to measure the loop will help keep it consistent notes *instead of fhdc you may chain 202 loosely then half_double_crochet in the 2nd chain from hook and across for the first row if you want a wider scarf add half_double_crochet row in multiples of 2 scarf can be made longer simply by adding additional row of double_crochet on the edges about the author christine welsh is an independent knitter and crocheter living and working on a small farm in southwest wisconsin she is inspired by the rugged landscape known as the driftless region to create knit and crochet wear that is both practical and beautiful you can find her on facebook under the name windy hill knitworks page 2 of 2
